organizations: Cathedral of Santa Maria la Menor

thread.title: 20 reasons why this country really does have it all
thread.title_full: 20 reasons why this country really does have it all

title: 20 reasons why this country really does have it all
text: 20 most beautiful places in the Dominican Republic Updated 1148 GMT (1848 HKT) October 12, 2015 21 photos: Playa Moron – Playa Moron is one of the gorgeous Samana Peninsula's smaller beaches. Visitors have a good chance of spotting a humpback whale during the January-March mating season. Hide Caption 1 of 21 21 photos: El Salto del Limon waterfall, Samana – It's a mile-and-a-half trek through the jungle to get to the top of the cascades. The reward is the 130-feet-high El Salto del Limon, which flows into a natural pool that's great for swimming. Hide Caption 2 of 21 21 photos: Cathedral of Santa Maria la Menor – Dating to 1512, the Cathedral of Santa Maria la Menor in Santo Domingo is widely considered the oldest cathedral in the Americas. Gothic architecture, 500-year-old mahogany doors and the former site of Christopher Columbus' tomb all wow visitors. Hide Caption 3 of 21 21 photos: Puerto Plata 'teleferico' – A popular excursion in Puerto Plata is the "teleferico" tour. Panoramic views of the city and ocean can be seen from the cable cars. A massive statue of Jesus Christ stands at the top of Mount Isabel de Torres. Hide Caption 4 of 21 21 photos: Los Haitises – The protected forest of Los Haitises has limited road access. It's become a popular eco-tourism destination, with most visitors arriving by boat. A variety of geographical landscapes are found in the region. Hide Caption 5 of 21 21 photos: Altos de Chavon, La Romana – Altos de Chavon is a massive replica 16th-century Mediterranean village. It's home to a cultural center, an archeological museum and an amphitheater, but just walking around is impressive. Hide Caption 6 of 21 21 photos: Playa Bayahibe, La Romana – Bayahibe Beach has a bar and a lighthouse and not much else, but it's known as one of the nicest places in the country to watch a sunset. Hide Caption 7 of 21 21 photos: Juanilo Beach, Punta Cana – Juanilo Beach is a calm, secluded public beach on the country's East Coast. Hide Caption 8 of 21 21 photos: Heroes de la Restauracion Monument, Santiago – The Monument to the Heroes of the Restoration of the Republic is an eight-story structure dedicated to Dominican soldiers who fought the final War of Independence against Spain. Hide Caption 9 of 21 21 photos: Baseball fields – From pro stadiums to dirt lots, any baseball field is a place of beauty in a country obsessed with the game. The DR sends more players to Major League Baseball than any country outside the United States, with 83 players on the list of Opening Day 2015 rosters. Hide Caption 10 of 21 21 photos: Bani Dunes, Barahona – The sand dunes of Barahona are the largest in the Caribbean. The flora of the area (cactus and shrubs) differs from the rest of the country. Barahona is also home to the largest lake in the Caribbean and a highway along the coast with breathtaking vistas. Hide Caption 11 of 21 21 photos: Damajagua, Puerto Plata – In Damajagua, you can hike an hour up a mountain and slide or jump down 27 waterfalls. Hide Caption 12 of 21 21 photos: Punta Cana – Punta Cana is a popular tourist and wedding destination, known for its impeccable white sand beaches. Hide Caption 13 of 21 21 photos: Ancient Puerto Plata – Remains of the first European settlement in the Americas are located in Puerto Plata. Christopher Columbus made landfall here in 1492. Hide Caption 14 of 21 21 photos: El Morro, Montecristi – El Morro of Montecristi rises 794 feet above sea level and is known as the guardian of the ancient city. Hide Caption 15 of 21 21 photos: Playa Rincon, Samana – Playa Rincon is located about 15 miles from the port of Samana on the northeast coast. The secluded beach stretches for two miles with only a few restaurants and bars. Hide Caption 16 of 21 21 photos: Fortaleza Ozama Museum – The fort was built in 1502 to protect Santo Domingo from pirates and foreign invaders. Visitors can take stairs to the top for panoramic views. Hide Caption 17 of 21 21 photos: Palacio Nacional – Santo Domingo's National Palace has never actually been the home of the Dominican president. It's used as an office building. The interior is decorated with mahogany furniture, gold and paintings from Dominican artists. Hide Caption 18 of 21 21 photos: Cueva de las Maravillas – These gigantic caves are home to more than 250 Taino cave drawings. The experience isn't complete without seeing the cave's stalactites, stalagmites and bat holes! Hide Caption 19 of 21 21 photos: La Basilica de Higuey – The Basilica of Higuey is one of the most important symbols in the Dominican Republic. The huge arch is about 262 feet high and gives the impression of praying hands. Hide Caption 20 of 21 21 photos: Carnival celebrations – OK, it's not technically a place but we can't resist mentioning the beauty, color and uniquely Dominican spirit of February Carnival celebrations throughout the country. Hide Caption 21 of 21 Back in 2008, the Dominican Republic's Ministry of Tourism glossed the DR as the country "that has it all." The country is still sticking with that slogan and it's easy to see why. Year-round tropical climate. Lush coastline with 250 miles of beaches. Historic cities and culture.
